Miss Louise Keen Dies As
Result Of Operation;
Gordon's Secretary
Miss Louise Keen, who for the
past two years has been secretary
to Dr. Neil E. Gordon, professor
of chemical education at the J. H.
U., died at the Johns Hopkins Hospital last Thursday, following a major operation.
When she began her secretarial
work here she was only 18 years
old. It was revealed by Dr. Gordon
that Miss Keen had intended pursuing her college studies by taking
French in the evening classes here
this term, just as she had studied
chemistry in her first 'year at the
Hopkins as a secretary.
Dr. Gordon praised the late secretary, saying that she was extremely accommodating, highly efficient, and a wizard at keeping details
accurately.

Reid sent the opening kickoff
deep into enemy territory, and Short
ran it back to the thirty-yard line.
After an exchange of kicks, Kelly
fumbled a Brown and White punt
and Fortman, right end, recovered
for the visitors on the Jays' twentyyard mark.
Three plays were aimed at the
line, but the Hopkins forwards stood
1 firm. On fourth down, a pass from

pigskin to the four-yard line, and
another toss via the same route
shoved Lehigh into a 6-0 lead.
Yearley blocked Suvalsky's attempt
to convert the extra point.

until late in the second period when
Reid intercepted a pass in midfield.
Kelly immediately skirted right end
for eleven yards. Two line plunges
availed nothing, but Kelly passed to
Reynolds for another first down on
the twenty-yard stripe.
Reynolds, Beeler and Kelly
smashed .the line with little success,
gaining a total of but two yards. On
fourth down Beeler faded back and
tossed a long pass over the goal line
where Kelly was waiting to gather
it in and deadlock the covnt at 6-6.
The half ended after Reid had
missed the try for point.

Dr. Fagin Says
After a number of weeks of intensive planning, Dr. N. Bryllion
Fagin, director of the Hopkins Playshop, has announced a program
which it is hoped will be even more
satisfactory to its subscribers than
the one of last year.
Three big dramatic bills will be
featured, aside from a series of five
lectures on the drama of several European countries. The first of the
big bills will consist of a production
of Moliere5s play "L'Avare", the
lines to be spoken in English. This
presentation will be preceded by a
lecture on the playwright to be delivered by Dr. H. Carrington Lancaster, chairman of the department
of Romance Languages.
Second on the season's repertoire
will be a group of three one-act
plays. It is hoped that the major
piece will be one written by Dr.
Euler concerning the struggle of
French culture in the American settlements of Louisiana. The other
two plays on this bill are to be selected from efforts of Dr. Fagin's
class in playwriting.
The new bill will be an orginal
full-length play by an American
author. Any playwright in the
country who has a play either produced or not, is invited to submit
it.
The series of lectures include one
by Dr. Fagin on the Soviet Theater.
He has visited Russia this summer
and aside from having seen several
productions, he has discussed drama
with directors. Dr. Einersson will
give a lecture on the Scandinavian
Theater and there will be lectures on
the Italian and American Theaters.
All of these lectures In' be illustrated by short playlets. Admittance
to the lectures is by subscription
ticket, costing $2.00.

Aboard the "Red Special"
truck at an open-air massmeeting
on the corner of St. Paul and 23rd

denounced the Democratic and Republican platforms and urged 200
Goucher students to vote for Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for
the Presidency, on the grounds that
the Socialist party "is the only party
which can present a solution for the
country's economic problems."

DeMolays And Masons In
University Invited To
Attend

:•:

The DeMolay Club luncheon will
be held tomorrow at 12.30 in the
Conference Room of Levering Hall.
All DeMolays and Masons in the
University are cordially invited to
attend, and may bring their own
lunch or be served from the cafeteria, as they desire.
The DeMolay Club was founded
at Homewood last year, and
has a membership Of about
thirty. Its purpose is to instill a
feeling of fellowship among members of the order here at the University. Among its officers are
Lester Dashiells, president, and
William Reitz, secretary-treasurer.

Miss Louise Keen Dies As
Result Of Operation;
Gordon's Secretary
Miss Louise Keen, who for the
past two years has been secretary
to Dr. Neil E. Gordon, professor
of chemical education at the J. H.
U., died at the Johns Hopkins Hospital last Thursday, following a major operation.
When she began her secretarial
work here she was only 18 years
old. It was revealed by Dr. Gordon
that Miss Keen had intended pursuing her college studies by taking
French in the evening classes here
this term, just as she had studied
chemistry in her first 'year at the
Hopkins as a secretary.
Dr. Gordon praised the late secretary, saying that she was extremely accommodating, highly efficient, and a wizard at keeping details

Reid sent the opening kickoff
deep into enemy territory, and Short
ran it back to the thirty-yard line.
After an exchange of kicks, Kelly
fumbled a Brown and White punt
and Fortman, right end, recovered
for the visitors on the Jays' twentyyard mark.
Three plays were aimed at the
line, but the Hopkins forwards stood
1 firm. On fourth down, a pass from

pigskin to the four-yard line, and
another toss via the same route
shoved Lehigh into a 6-0 lead.
Yearley blocked Suvalsky's attempt
to convert the extra point.

Reid intercepted a pass in midfield.

for eleven yards. Two line plunges
availed nothing, but Kelly passed to

the twenty-yard stripe.
Reynolds, Beeler and Kelly
smashed .the line with little success,
gaining a total of but two yards. On
fourth down Beeler faded back and
tossed a long pass over the goal line
where Kelly was waiting to gather
it in and deadlock the covnt at 6-6.
The half ended after Reid had
missed the try for point.

Dr. Fagin Says
After a number of weeks of intensive planning, Dr. N. Bryllion
Fagin, director of the Hopkins Playshop, has announced a program
which it is hoped will be even more
satisfactory to its subscribers than
the one of last year.
Three big dramatic bills will be
featured, aside from a series of five
lectures on the drama of several European countries. The first of the
big bills will consist of a production
of Moliere5s play "L'Avare", the
lines to be spoken in English. This
presentation will be preceded by a
lecture on the playwright to be delivered by Dr. H. Carrington Lancaster, chairman of the department
of Romance Languages.
Second on the season's repertoire
will be a group of three one-act
plays. It is hoped that the major
piece will be one written by Dr.
Euler concerning the struggle of
French culture in the American settlements of Louisiana. The other
two plays on this bill are to be selected from efforts of Dr. Fagin's
class in playwriting.
The new bill will be an orginal
full-length play by an American
author. Any playwright in the
country who has a play either produced or not, is invited to submit
it.
The series of lectures include one
by Dr. Fagin on the Soviet Theater.
He has visited Russia this summer
and aside from having seen several
productions, he has discussed drama
with directors. Dr. Einersson will
give a lecture on the Scandinavian
Theater and there will be lectures on
the Italian and American Theaters.
All of these lectures In' be illustrated by short playlets. Admittance
to the lectures is by subscription
ticket, costing $2.00.

Aboard the "Red Special"
truck at an open-air massmeeting
on the corner of St. Paul and 23rd
Streets, members of the Johns Hopkins Thomas-For-President Club
denounced the Democratic and Republican platforms and urged 200
Goucher students to vote for Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for
the Presidency, on the grounds that
the Socialist party "is the only party
which can present a solution for the
country's economic problems."

DeMolays And Masons In
University Invited To
Attend

:•:

The DeMolay Club luncheon will
be held tomorrow at 12.30 in the
Conference Room of Levering Hall.
All DeMolays and Masons in the
University are cordially invited to
attend, and may bring their own
lunch or be served from the cafeteria, as they desire.
The DeMolay Club was founded
at Homewood last year, and
has a membership Of about
thirty. Its purpose is to instill a
feeling of fellowship among members of the order here at the University. Among its officers are
Lester Dashiells, president, and
William Reitz, secretary-treasurer.
